questions.text: Which is the vital layer of the cornea?
questions.solution:
The two main roles of corneal endothelial cells are:

  1. Barrier function, which is mediated by proteins such as zonula occludens-1
  2. Pump function, which is mediated by an active (Na+/K+-ATPase) pump. The active Na+/K+-ATPase pump osmotically draws water and ions from the corneal stroma into the aqueous humor, which helps to maintain the relatively dehydrated state of the stroma.

Thereby, it helps in maintain normal corneal thickness and transparency. For this reason. the endothelium is considered to be the vital layer of the cornea

questions.text: This is the image of a patient with ICE syndrome. Which subtype is this?
questions.solution:
Irido-Corneal Endothelial syndrome ICE syndrome is a rare corneal disease characterized by structural and proliferative abnormalities of endothelial cells.

It typically affects adults (more often women in the third to fifth decades of life) is sporadic in presentation and usually unilateral

The major subtypes of this disease include:

  1. Chandler syndrome
  2. Cogan-Reese syndrome
  3. Progressive(essential) iris atrophy

 

Corneal edema and secondary glaucoma are the most common causes of reduced vision in ICE syndrome.

Cogan-Reese syndrome is characterized by:

  • Matted or smudged appearance of the iris
  • Nodular iris nevi(seen in the image)
  • Peripheral anterior synechiae
  • Ectropion uveae(seen in the image)
  • Glaucoma(in the image, peripheral iridotomy, for angle closure glaucoma, is seen at 11 o’clock)

questions.text: A 55-year old diabetic and ischemic heart disease patient present with painless decrease in vision. His OCT and FFA are shown below. All of the following is the most likely cause of this presentation:
questions.solution:
OCT shows cystoid macular edema with cysts in the Outer plexiform layer(Henle’s layer). However, the FFA of Right eye does not show any leakage of dye in the macula.  

Fluorescein leakage at the macula is typically present in cases of macular edema. However, in certain conditions, despite observation of macular edema on clinical examination and on OCT, the petaloid appearance caused by fluorescein dye leakage typical of CME is absent on FFA. The causes of non-leaking macular edema are:

  1. Nicotinic acid maculopathy
  2. Goldman Favre Syndrome
  3. Juvenile X-linked Retinoschisis
  4. Enhanced S-cone dystrophy

Nicotinic acid maculopathy affects more frequently men, with a male : female ratio of 10 : 1

Niacin maculopathy generally occurs at doses of 3 g per day or more.

Niacin (a combination of nicotinic acid and nicotinamide), a B vitamin (vitamin B3), is a pharmacotherapeutic agent. Niacin is the most potent agent used to increase plasma high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol.

In patients with diabetes mellitus or mixed dyslipidemia, niacin has been shown to decrease cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, especially when used in combination with statins.

In diabetic patients, frequent monitoring of blood glucose is necessary as niacin can increase fasting blood glucose.

questions.text: These particles in the vitreous are composed of:
questions.solution:
This is Asteroid Hyalosis

  • Type of vitreous degeneration in which calcium soaps aggregate in vitreous body.
  • Seen in older patients
  • Male to female ratio 2:1
  • Rarely affects patient's visual acuity
  • Signs:
    • White to yellow-white small round to oval opacities suspended throughout the vitreous body
    • Unilateral in 75-90%
    • Asteroid bodies move as the vitreous body move and tend to return to their original positions
  • No treatment is required.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely complication due to this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows MICROSPHEROPHAKIA. The entire equator if the lens is visible through a dilated pupil – Microphakia

Causes of microspherophakia:

Common causes of microspherophakia

  • Weil-Marchesani syndrome
  • Marfan’s syndrome
  • Lowe’s syndrome

The small and spherical lens causes zonular stretching resulting in lens dislocated. The dislocated lens moves anteriorly and blocks the pupillary area, resulting in blockage of the aqueous movement from PC to AC. This results in increase in accumulation of aqueous in the PC and forward movement of iris. Forward movement of the iris causes a secondary angle closure.

Such a precipitation of secondary angle closure glaucoma would necessitate emergency management:

  • Patient is made to lie supine
  • Topical Mydriatic-cycloplegic(atropine ideally) is instilled – to dislodge the lens from obstructing the pupil. Hence, this type of glaucoma is called “Inverse glaucoma”(Usually, mydriatics are contraindicated in angle closure glaucomas)

Subsequently:

  • Clear lens extraction is done(ICCE technique)

questions.text: Which of the most common ocular finding in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
• Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies (AChR-Abs) are present in up to 99% of patients with generalized myasthenia and 40-77% of patients with ocular MG.
  • AChR-Abs decrease the number of available AChRs by:
  1. receptor blockade
  2. complement-mediated membrane damage and
  3. accelerated degradation of the receptors

This results in defective transmission at the neuro-muscular junction and subsequent muscle weakness.

  • Variable ptosis is one of the most common manifestations of myasthenia gravis. It may be unilateral or bilateral– in bilateral cases, it is often asymmetrical.
  • Lid fatigability test - Ptosis increases with prolonged upgaze
  • Cogan's lid twitch: When the patient looks from downgaze to primary position, there is a quick overshooting upward movement followed by a down-drift of the upper lid.

Lagophthalmos is incomplete lid closure on attempted closing, due to facial nerve palsy or massive proptosis

Exophthalmos is proptosis due to thyroid eye disease

Lid retraction is the most common ocular finding of thyroid eye disease

questions.text: Chemotherapy regimen of choice for retinoblastoma is?
questions.solution:
The standard chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine, etoposide, and carboplatin (VEC protocol). These are administered for at least six cycles at 4-week intervals. This is employed for ICRB Group A, B, C and D tumors



After two cycles of chemotherapy and the tumor size and subretinal fluid have been reduced, local treatment methods are used. The most frequently used local treatment methods are:

  1. Cryotherapy
  2. Transpupillary thermotherapy(TTT)
  3. Plaque radiotherapy(brachytherapy)

choices.text: Right Inferior Oblique and Left Superior Rectus
Right Superior Oblique and Left Inferior Rectus
Right Inferior Rectus and Left Superior Oblique
Right Medial Rectus and Left Inferior Rectus

questions.text: Yoke muscles performing this gaze:
questions.solution:
This gaze is Levodepression

SUPERIOR OBLIQUE performs 'DEPRESION OF ADDUCTED EYE'. Here, right eye is adducted and has been depressed. So Right Superior Oblique.

INFERIOR RECTUS performs 'DEPRESSION OF ABDUCTED EYE'. Here, left eye is abducted and has been depressed. So, Left Inferior Rectus

Therefore, the yoke muscles for levodepression are RIGHT SUPERIOR OBLIQUE AND LEFT INFERIOR RECTUS

questions.text: Presence of extra layer of cilia posterior to grey line is:
questions.solution:
Cilia refers to eyelashes

  • Distichiasis is a condition clinically presenting as partial or complete accessory row of lashes that emerge from the meibomian glands orifices.
  • It is due to metaplasia of meibomian glands
  • It can be:
    • acquired or S
    • congenital with an autosomal dominant inheritance

It should be clinically differentiated from ectopic cilia, which are usually thicker and well pigmented, similar to normal lashes and are present in the anterior lamella

Distichiatic lashes are thinner, hypopigmented and arise in the posterior lamella (posterior to the grey line)

questions.text: Characteristic feature of fungal keratitis is:
questions.solution:
features suggestive of fungal keratitis:

  1. Elevated edges
  2. Feathery margins
  3. Rough and dry texture and Satellite lesions
  4. Hypopyon

The hypopyon is typically infected, immobile(fixed). Satellite lesions are more characteristic than hypopyon. Hypoyon may be seen in many other conditions like endophthalmitis, uveitis.

In cases of fungal keratitis due to filamentous fungi(Aspergillus, Fusarium), there may be a history of trauma with vegetative matter

In cases of fungal keratitis due to yeast fungi may have a history of an ocular surface disease or immunosuppression with a clinical picture that resembles more bacterial keratitis but with a slower progression.

The diagnosis is by corneal scrapings. Samples should be sent for PCR and cultures.

questions.text: Fundus examination in a patient shows chalky white optic disc with well-defined margins. CDR is 0.9, cup is deep and NRR is almost absent. Retinal vessels and surrounding retina appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The neuroretinal rim(NRR) is the most important parameter of the optic disk evaluation. The normal optic disc is vertically oval and the cup is horizontally oval.

Thus, the rim has a characteristic configuration where the inferior (I) rim is the widest, followed by the superior (S) and nasal rims (N) and the temporal (T) rim is the thinnest. This is the ‘ISNT rule' which helps to determine glaucomatous changes in the disc.

The cardinal feature of glaucomatous optic neuropathy is the loss of NRR from the inner edge of the rim.  The neuroretinal rim  becomes thinned over time due to actual physical loss of ganglion cells.  The sequence of loss is usually first in the inferotemporal and superotemporal disk regions.

Eventually, optic atrophy occurs which is cavernous or excavated in appearance and is a primary optic atrophy.

questions.text: Identify the squint:
questions.solution:
Definition and Classification

  1. A- Pattern: - (Minimum of 10 prism dioptre difference between up and down gaze)

a) A - Esotropia (Esophoria):- Here, the convergent deviation increases in direct upward gaze and decreases in downward gaze.

b) A - Exotropia (Exophoria):- Here, divergent deviation increases in downward gaze than when looking directly upward.

  1. V- Pattern: - (Minimum of 15 prism dioptre difference between up and down gaze)

a) V- Esotropia (Esophoria):- The convergent deviation is greater when looking directly downward than when looking directly upward (seen in this image)

b) V- Exotropia (Exophoria):- The divergent deviation is greater when looking directly upward than when looking directly downward

choices.text: Retained intra ocular iron foreign body

questions.text: Pre-requisite for a diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis:
questions.solution:
Sympathetic ophthalmia (SO) is a bilateral diffuse granulomatous uveitis following penetrating trauma or ocular surgery involving one eye. Following trauma to one globe (the exciting eye), intraocular inflammation develops in the fellow eye (the sympathizing eye).

Findings range from mild anterior uveitis to severe panuveitis - mutton-fat keratic precipitates, vitritis, papillitis, and serous retinal detachments.

Dalen-Fuch’s nodules are a classic finding present in only 25% to 35% of cases. These nodules are composed of subretinal RPE epithelioid cells.

OCT findings include focal nodular hyperreflective lesions at the level of the RPE, which correspond clinically with Dalen-Fuchs nodules

 

The sine quo non for sympathetic ophthalmitis is the penetrating injury.  VKH syndrome has similar clinical features in the eye except for the history of penetrating eye trauma.

Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis, often associated with a prodrome of meningeal and auditory symptoms. The disease may have clinical and histopathologic features identical to sympathetic ophthalmia in both the acute and in the chronic phase. However, findings such as vitiligo and alopecia are more common in Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome than in sympathetic ophthalmia. A history of penetrating trauma is helpful in this differential diagnosis.

questions.text: Unilateral proptosis with bilateral abducens nerve palsy is seen in:
questions.solution:
Within the lumen of the cavernous sinuses pass:

  1. horizontal segment of the internal carotid artery
  2. sympathetic plexus
  3. Abducens nerve

The outer layers of the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus are traversed by cranial nerves:

  1. III (oculomotor)
  2. IV (trochlear)
  3. V (the first and second divisions - ophthalmic and maxillary, of the trigeminal)

Cavernous sinus thrombosis leads to decreased drainage from the facial vein and superior and inferior ophthalmic veins resulting in facial and periorbital edema, ptosis, proptosis, chemosis, discomfort and pain with eye muscle movement, papilledema, retinal venous distention, and loss of vision.

Orbital cellulitis spreads via the ophthalmic veins into the cavernous sinus.

Also, communication between the right and left cavernous sinuses via the intercavernous sinuses, anterior and posterior to the sella, allows the spread of  infection from one side to the other.

Sixth cranial nerve palsy is the most common and the earliest neuropathy, resulting in partial ophthalmoplegia with limited eye abduction. 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is usually septic, but can also be aseptic.

 Septic cases can follow central facial infections, especially within the danger triangle of the face (from the corners of the mouth to the bridge of the nose).

  • Causes include orbital cellulitis, sinusitis (especially sphenoiditis and ethmoiditis), dental infections, extractions or procedures (even a posterior superior alveolar nerve block entering the pterygoid plexus), maxillofacial surgery, otitis media, and mastoiditis.

Aseptic causes are less common than septic causes. These include trauma, surgery, or pregnancy

A variety of infectious organisms can cause cavernous sinus thrombosis although the majority are bacterial. Staphylococcus aureus may account for two-thirds of cases

questions.text: In near vision, what change occurs?
questions.solution:
Accommodation triad:

  1. Converegence of both eyes ( medial recti contract; so option C ruled out)
  2. Bilateral miosis(when aperture size decreases, the depth of focus increases)
  3. Increase in anterior curvature of lens

Increase in anterior curvature of lens results in increase in dioptric power of the lens(option A)

During accommodation, the zonules relax.; so, the tension decreases

choices.text: Sea fan appearance seen more commonly in supero-temporal retina
HBSS has severe ocular manifestations than HBSC

questions.text: What is incorrect regarding sickle cell retinopathy?
questions.solution:
• NON-PROLIFERATIVE sickle cell retinopathy(NPSCR), more commonly observed in HbSS patients
  • PROLIFERATIVE sickle cell retinopathy(PSCR) is more commonly observed in HbSC patients
  • In PSCR, retinal vascular occlusions cause tissue ischemia and release of angiogenic mediators that promote retinal neovascularization (ie, neovascular proliferation). Then, this seafan neovascularization, a hallmark in PSCR patients, grows anteriorly from the perfused to non-perfused (avascular) retina to reach the posterior ischemic retina

choices.text: Bones of orbital wall and periorbita

questions.text: Peripheral space lies between:
questions.solution:
The space between the periorbita and the four extraocular muscles is called the peripheral orbital space or the anterior space

Surgical spaces in orbit:

The orbit is divisible into four spaces. Knowledge of the main compartments of the orbit and their boundaries helps in choosing the most direct approach to the tumor.

  1. Central space
  • It is also called muscular cone or posterior or retrobulbar space.
  • Contents of this space include optic nerve and its meninges, superior and inferior divisions of oculomotor nerve, abducent nerve, nasociliary nerve, ciliary ganglion, ophthalmic artery, superior ophthalmic vein and central orbital fat.
  • Many of the circumscribed orbital tumors such as cavernous hemangioma, solitary neurofibroma, meningioma, optic nerve glioma occur in this space and usually produce axial proptosis. Such tumors are aften removed through a lateral orbitotomy.
  1. Subperiosteal space

This is a potential space between orbital bones and the periorbita.

Dermoid cyst, epidermoid cyst, mucocele, subperiosteal abscess are commonly seen in this space.

  1. Peripheral Orbital space (Anterior space)
  • This space is bounded peripherally by periorbita, internally by the four extra ocular muscles, anteriorly by the orbital septum. Posteriorly, it merges with the central soace.
  • Tumors present in this space produce eccentric proptosis and can usually be palpated. Common tumors present in this space are malignant lymphoma, capillary hemangioma, neoplasms of the lacrimal gland and pseudotumors.
  • Tumors residing in this space are explored mostly by anterior orbitotomy.
  1. Sub- Tenon’s space
  • It is a potential space around the eyeball between the sclera and tenon’s capsule.
  • Pus collected in this space is drained by incision of tenon’s capsule through the conjunctiva.

questions.text: OCT(Optical coherence tomography) is based on:
questions.solution:
Optical Coherence Tomography(OCT)  produces high resolution, cross sectional images of ocular structures in vivo. OCT produces detailed two dimensional images of the retina and measures retinal thickness with a longitudinal image resolution of approximately 10 microns. The principles of OCT are similar to B-mode ultrasound, however OCT utiIizes the reflection of Iight waves from different structures in the eye rather than sound.

Low coherent light, produced  by a continous wave superluminescent diode(810nm) source, is directed into the eye and is reflected at the boundaries of tissues with different optical properties

AS-OCT(anterior segment OCT) is used to visualise the cornea, angle, iris and lens.

questions.text: The following is used in Collagen cross-linking:
questions.solution:
Corneal collagen cross-linking is a technique which uses UV-A light and a photosensitizer(riboflavin) to strengthen corneal stroma by strengthening existing covalent bonds or creating new bonds between the collagen fibrils in the corneal stroma (Photo-polymerisation)

Indication:

To halt progressive and irregular changes in corneal ectasia

  1. Keratoconus
  2. Post-LASIK ectasia

Contraindications:

  • Corneal thickness of less than 400 microns
  • Prior herpetic infection is a contraindication because it may result in viral reactivation
  • Concurrent infection
  • Severe corneal scarring or opacification
  • History of poor epithelial wound healing (as in diabetes)
  • Severe ocular surface disease (eg. dry eye)
  • Autoimmune disorders

questions.text: Eyelea (Aflibercept):
questions.solution:
Anti-VEGFs for intravitreal use are:

  • Monoclonal antibody - Bevacizumab (Avastin)
  • Antibody derivative - Ranibizumab (Lucentis)
  • Aptamer - Pegaptanib (Macugen)
  • Fusion proteins - Aflibercept (VEGF-Trap, Eyelea)
  • si-RNA – Bevasiranib

questions.text: In pterygium, elastotic degeneration occurs in which layer?
questions.solution:
There is fragmentation of Bowman’s layer and elastosis.

Elastotic material within pterygium is formed in the following ways:

  1. by degenerated collagen
  2. by degeneration of pre-existing elastic fibers
  3. by abnormal fibroblastic activity

questions.text: Lens contains which antigen
questions.solution:
Lens is an immunoprivileged organ wherein the lens proteins have never been exposed to the immune system of the body and hence are considered 'sequestered antigens'.

Trauma with rupture of capsule results in the release of these sequestered lens proteins and accounts for the resulting inflammatory response seen in phacoanaphylactic uveitis.

questions.text: An autoimmune condition included as phakomatosis is:
questions.solution:
Phakomatoses, also known as neurocutaneous syndromes

Congenital disorders that are characterized by hamartomatous lesions of the skin and the central and peripheral nervous systems

  1. Neurofibromatosis
  2. Tuberous sclerosis
  3. von Hippel-Lindau)
  4. Sturge-Weber syndrome
  5. Ataxia-telangiectasia

 

Ataxia telangiectasia (AT) is an autosomal recessive condition that is caused by mutations in the AT gene localized on chromosome 11

People with A-T have an increased risk of developing autoimmune or chronic inflammatory diseases. This risk is probably a secondary effect of their immunodeficiency and not a direct effect of the lack of ATM protein. The most common examples of such disorders in A-T include immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), several forms of arthritis, and vitiligo.

 Abnormal eye findings associated with A-T include:

  • Oculomotor apraxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Strabismus

questions.text: Which vitamin supplementation may be helpful in preventing ectopia lentis in homocystinuria?
questions.solution:
• Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation has been shown to reduce the incidence of ectopia lentis in homocystinuria


  • Vitamin B6non-responders may benefit from a diet:
    • low in methionine and
    • supplementation with cystine

questions.text: Which is the first gene known to cause hereditary, nonsyndromic age-related cortical cataracts?
questions.solution:
• EPHA2 is the first gene known to cause hereditary, nonsyndromic age-related cortical
  • Located on 1p36

questions.text: Sunflower cataract is seen in
questions.solution:
The underlying mechanism of Sunflower cataract formation would help you remember the conditions in which it is seen.

Copper gets deposited as cuprous oxide in basement membranes because of its affinity to type 4 collagen found in basement membranes.

The target basement membranes in the eye are:

  1. Anterior capsule – Sunflower cataract
  2. Descemet’s membrane – Kayser Fleischer ring

Conditions where excess copper is found:

  1. Wislon’s disease(systemic copper toxicity)
  2. Chalcosis ( Ocular copper toxicity)

questions.text: 'Snow ball' opacity in vitreous is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Collection of vitreous cells and exudates results in “snowball opacities” in the vitreous. Seen in pars planitis. Sarcoidosis is the most common cause of pars planitis
  • Vitreous cells may be seen in Fuch’s heterochromic iridocyclitis; not snowballs though.

choices.text: hyperemia of the optic nerve head
waxy pallor color of optic nerve head

questions.text: All of the following are fundus findings of LEBER'S HEREDITARY OPTIC NEUROPATHY (LHON) except:
questions.solution:
Fundus findings of LHON:

  • hyperemia of the optic nerve head
  • dilation and tortuosity of vessels
  • disc hemorrhages
  • circumpapillary telangiectatic microangiopathy
  • circumpapillary nerve fiber layer swelling that does not leak on FFA (pseudoedema)

questions.text: In patients with anterior uveitis, decrease in vision due to involvement of posterior segment can occur because of:
questions.solution:
Chronic and/or recurrent anterior uveitis may be complicated by posterior segment involvement – inflammatory macular edema. This results in permanent decrease in vision.

Vitreous cells would cause the symptom of floaters

Disc edema per se, due to any cause, does not affect vision

questions.text: Congenital cataract occurs due to abnormalities in protein formation in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
• CRYBA, CRYBB, CRYGA, CRYGB, CRYGC, CRYGD, and CRYGS gene mutations are only associated with inherited congenital cataract and no other systemic or eye anomalies 
  • PAX6 gene is
  • Located on 11p13
  • Autosomal dominant
  • PAX gene mutation results in congenital cataract along with other eye findings:
    • Aniridia
    • Foveal hypoplasia
    • Nystagmus
    • Corneal abnormalities
    • Developmental glaucoma

questions.text: The test being performed is:
questions.solution:
Krimsky’s test is used to measure the angle of squint where the prism of appropriate magnitude is held in front of the fixating eye until the light on the cornea is centred in the pupil

Modified Krimsky’s test is when the prism is held in front of the squinting eye.

questions.text: A 45-year old man presents with difficulty while reading and while climbing downstairs. On examination, there is right hypotropia and a right-sided head tilt. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In left superior oblique palsy, there is left IO overaction(which is an elevator) resulting in right  hypertropia or left hypotropia. The patient adopts a head tilt to opposite shoulder (right side, in this case).

As superior oblique depresses an adducted eye(the eyeball’s position during reading and climbing downstairs), the patient would have difficulty/diplopia during these activities

questions.text: All conditions may be associated with buphthalmos:
questions.solution:
Marfan’s syndrome and Lowe’s syndrome are associated with trabeculodysgenesis and developmental glaucoma resulting in buphthalmos.

In retinoblastoma, there can be secondary glaucoma due to infiltration of the tumor cells in the ciliary body and anterior movement of the lens-iris diaphragma causing secondary angle closure or infiltration of the trabecular meshwork by tumor cells resulting in secondary open angle glaucoma. In a young child, this could result in enlargement of the eyeball - buphthalmos

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest letter in the Snellen chart on a person's eye who is reading it from a distance of 6 meters
questions.solution: Largest letter on Snellen's chart corresponds to 60m distance

questions.text: A 26-year old female presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. There is history of multiple episodes of diminution of vision with recovery on treatment with steroids and also history of transverse myelitis. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
NEUROMYELITIS OPTICA (NMO)

  • Also known as Devic’s disease
  • Optic neuritis(usually bilateral) withtransverse myelitis
  • May be monophasic or recurrent
  • Recurrent disease is associated with:
    • Worse prognosis
    • Higher morbidity rate
  • NMO diagnostic criteria includes the NMO-IgG

This differentiates NMO from multiple sclerosis

NMO-IgG is directed against Aquaporin-4

  • Mainstay treatment for acute episodes:
    • High-dose steroids + Plasmapheresis

Other drugs:

Immunosuppressants

  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Azathioprine
  • Rituximab (anti-CD 20)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought for the complaint of protrusion of the right eye since 10 days with no history of fever. CT scan showed well-defined mass in the right orbit with irregular borders and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which is positive for Desmin on Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The older age of the child presenting with proptosis suggests RMS (average age 7 to 8 years) than RB (average age at presentation is 18 months).

Rhabdomyosarcoma is classified into 4 major histological subtypes

  1. Embryonal: Makes up 80% of orbital rhabdomyosarcomas and presents most commonly in young children (mean age 7-8)
  2. Alveolar subtype exhibits small, round, densely appearing cells that are loosely arranged, with septae that are similar to the alveoli of the lung; carries the worst prognosis
  3. Botryoid - variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma; subepithelial grape-like aggregates of tumor cells; seen most commonly in infants
  4. Pleomorphic

 

Immunohistochemistry is useful in identifying skeletal muscle proteins, such as

  • Alpha-actin
  • Myosin
  • Desmin
  • Myoglobin

questions.text: Key-hole shaped visual field defect is seen in lesion involving which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
For example, lesion of left LGB would cause:

Right homonymous sectoranopia

questions.text: Hypotonic maculopathy can result from all except:
questions.solution:
Hypotony maculopathy

  • Defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg
  • Associated fundus changes:
  • Chorioretinal folds
  • Disc edema and
  • Tortuous retinal veins

Causes:

  • Excessive filtration following trabeculectomy (MCC), especially with mitomycin C use
  • Trauma (cyclodialysis cleft, penetrating injury)
  • Chronic uveitis (ciliary body atrophy)
  • Retinal detachment
  • Systemic causes of hypotony (usually bilateral):
    • Dehydration
    • Hyperglycaemia in uncontrolled diabetes

 

Suprachoroidal haemorrhage is associated with high IOP.

Risk factors for suprachoroidal haemorrhage are:

  • Axial length greater than 25 mm
  • High myopia
  • Advanced age
  • Atherosclerosis /High blood pressure
  • Pseudophakia
  • Anticoagulants

questions.text: The centre for vertical gaze is:
questions.solution:
• Center for vertical saccades: rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF)
  • Center for vertical gaze-holding function (the vertical and torsional neural integrator): Interstitial nucleus of Cajal (INC)


Dysfunction of vertical eye movements in midbrain lesion which affects:

  1. riMLF
  2. Interstitial nucleus of Cajal or
  3. Posterior commissure (as in Parinaud’s dorsal midbrain syndrome)

Causes:

  • Infarction or bleeding in the upper midbrain
  • Chronic progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP)
  • Niemann-Pick type C (NP-C)

choices.text: The steep and flat meridians are perpendicular to each other
The horizontal meridian is the flatter meridian
The steep axis is at 180 degrees
The convex cylinder is oriented along the vertical meridian

questions.text: Regarding with-the-rule astigmatism, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
With-the-rule astigmatism:

With-the-rule astigmatism is a type of regular astigmatism where the vertical meridian(90 degrees) is steep and the horizontal meridian(180 degrees) is flat.

Convex(plus)cylinder is oriented along the vertical meridian or 90 degrees(steeper meridian)

Concave(minus) cylinder is oriented along the horizontal meridian or 180 degrees(flatter meridian)

questions.text: Where is the cell body of the second-order neuron in the sympathetic pathway for the pupil?
questions.solution:
The sympathetic pathway consists of a chain of three neurons.

  1. The first-order neuron arises from the hypothalamus and passes along the brain stem to synapse in the  intermediolateral column of the spinal cord at(C8-T1).
  2. From C8-T1- ciliospinal center of Budge(C8-T1), the second-order neuron arises. This joins the cervical sympathetic chain and synapses at the superior cervical ganglion.
  3. The third-order neuron arises from the superior cervical ganglion and travels through the cavernous sinus along with the internal carotid artery. Sympathetic fibres join the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and pass through the ciliary ganglion to the nasociliary and long ciliary nerves

questions.text: Patient has areas of yellowish papular skin lesions and redundant and inelastic folds of skin on the neck and thighs. Which of the following ocular finding is not seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ocular findings in Pseudoxanthoma elasticum:

  • Blue sclera
  • Angioid streaks
  • Optic nerve head drusen
  • 'Peau - d & rsquo;orange' appearance of the retina
  • Choroidal neovascular membrane(CNVM)

Angioid streaks are ruptures of Bruch’s membrane, which have been calcified.

CNVM-Causes:

  1. Neovascular age related macular degeneration
  2. Ocular Histoplasmosis Syndrome
  3. Angioid Streaks
  4. Pathologic Myopia
  5. Idiopathic CNVM
  6. Choroidal rupture from ocular trauma
  7. Intense photocoagulation(iatrogeni

choices.text: Goldmann contact lens and slit lamp

questions.text: Which optical instrument provides an inverted and reversed image of the retina?
questions.solution:
All the other options produce a virtual and erect image of the fundus.

Hruby lens is a Plano-concave lens with diopteric power of -58.6D

questions.text: Most common of conjunctivitis of newborn is caused by:
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of Ophthalmia neonatorum is Chlamydia trachomatis(serotypes D to K).
    • The baby as well the parents have to be treated
    • Treatment of baby:

    The most blinding cause of Ophthalmia neonatorum is Neisseria gonorrheae

questions.text: What type of presbyopic lenses is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Unlike bifocal lenses, progressive lenses have no line of demarcation on the lens and are gradually optimized for reading, distance and also for intermediate, such as computer work.

The other types of presbyopic glasses:



Executive type is preferred for pediatric aphakes/pseudophakes

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Simple myopic astigmatism is when one focal line is on the retina and the other focal line is focussed in front of the retina.

This means that there is only a minus cylinder needed for the correction of astigmatism.

Also, in the option C, minus cylinder is at 180 degrees which means the horizontal meridian is flat. Therefore, it is With-the-rule astigmatism(vertical steep and horizontal flat)

Option A is Hypermetropia

Option C is myopia

Option D is Simple hypermetropic astigmatism. Also, in the option D, plus cylinder is at 180 degrees which means the horizontal meridian is flat. Therefore, it is Against-the-rule astigmatism(horizontal steep and vertical flat)

choices.text: It is triangular in cross section
There are around 30-40 ciliary processes in each eye
Ciliary epithelium is formed from the anterior edge of optic cup
The pars plana is approximately 4.5mm from the limbus

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding ciliary body except:
questions.solution:
• There are around 60-70 ciliary processes(pars plicata) in each eye
  • Ciliary epithelium is derived from the neuroectoderm by the continued growth of the anterior edge of the optic cup(neuroectoderm)
  • Distances from limbus:
    • Pars plana: 4.5mm
    • Equator: 14mm

choices.text: Faulty migration of neural crest cells

questions.text: What developmental anomaly has caused this presentation as seen in the fundus picture?
questions.solution:
There is a chorioretinal coloboma below the optic disc.



This  is due to incomplete closure of the embryonic/choroidal fissure. These  colobomas may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris. This is the reason for typical colobomas to be located infero-nasally(the location of embryonic fissure)

 

Faulty migration of neural crest cells results in anterior segment dysgenesis.

questions.text: The following finding is diagnostic of:
questions.solution: This B-scan ultrasound image shows the T-sign due to sub-Tenon’s fluid in case of posterior scleritis

questions.text: The given fundus image shows:
questions.solution:
Drusen are the hallmark of dry AMD(Age-related Macular Degeneration)

Based on their size:

  • Small drusen (“drupelets”) are less than 63?µm in diameter
  • Intermediate drusen are 63 to 125?µm
  • Large drusen are greater than 125?µm.

Small drusen are considered normal aging and do not represent a risk for progression to advanced AMD.

 

AMD has been categorized by The Age-Related Eye Disease Study (AREDS) based on exam findings of hard drusen, soft drusen, RPE abnormalities, atrophy, and choroidal neovascularization; the AREDS categories are as follows:

  • Category 1 (No AMD): 
    • No drusen or
    • A few (5-15) small (<63µm) drusen  without pigment changes
  • Category 2 (Early AMD): Several small drusen, few intermediate-sized (63-124µm) drusen, and/or pigmentary changes in one or both eyes
  • Category 3 (Intermediate AMD): Extensive intermediate-sized drusen, one large (>125µm) druse, and/or geographic atrophy not involving the macula in one or both eyes
  • Category 4 (Advanced unilateral AMD): Advanced dry form (i.e., macula-involving geographic atrophy) or exudative form with choroidal neovascularization in one eye
  • Category 4a: Advanced AMD in one eye with category 1, 2, or 3 AMD in the fellow eye
  • Category 4b: Advanced AMD in one eye and decreased visual acuity (<20/32) secondary to AMD in the fellow eye; however, advanced AMD is not present in both eyes
